topic.title: Installing HP Helion OpenStack® 2.0 Using the UI

body.section: HP Helion OpenStack 2.0 Beta 2 comes with a UI for installing your cloud. Rather than searching through and editing a number of YAML files to input your specific configuration data, finding the correct location, and maintaing the format of the files, the UI presents fields in which you may enter your information.

In addition, rather than having to run a series of commands to execute the cobbler and ansible scripts that initiate the installation of HP Helion OpenStack, the UI application runs them behind the scenes.

While the UI app does more than simply popoulate the configuration files that the configuration processor uses as input to its processses, it does populate them. Therefore you can inspect the files whenever you like, or before reconfiguing your cloud.
These YAML configuration files are now stored in a local git repository as well, as explained in Using git for Configuration Manangement.

Before you begin Before you run the GUI installer to install your cloud, there are a number of things you need to do to prepare.
Prepare your servers
Gather your information
Server names
IP addresses
Server Roles
PXE MAC addresses
PXE IP addresses
PXE interfaces
IPMI/iLO IP address, username, password
Choose your cloud model/example template. Note that the only option for the Cloud model on KVM with VSA is the have 3 VSA nodes; there is no option to have 0 VSA nodes. Note also that you cannot put the deployer on a control plane node using the GUI installer.
Before you use the GUI to install your cloud, you must install the operating system, HP Linux for HP Helion OpenStack, on your nodes (servers) based on your hypervisor. You must do so by following the appropriate installation instructions.
KVM
ESX

Running the GUI to install your cloud Now that the OS, HP Linux for HP Helion OpenStack, is installed on all your servers (nodes), you will configure and install your cloud using the GUI.
The GUI is found on the deployer node at: http://<Deployer_IP>:79/dayzero Make sure you choose "NO" to the question of whether you want the Day0 installer to install the HP Linux for HP Helion OpenStack operatig system on your nodes.
To create a secure tunnel/port forwarding into Apache from the deployer to be able to use the GUI in a browser, SSH tunnel into the deployer with the username/password set up when installing the deployer. Username and password should be what was set in "Set up the Deployer" in the installation instructions. For example: ssh -v -N -L 8080:<Deployer_IP>:79 <Username>@<Deployer_IP>
Then on your local machine, point your web browser to: http://localhost:8080/dayzero As you proceed through the GUI, you need only supply your server names and IP addresses.

In the Assign network groups: External VM network fields, do not add entries for CIDR, Gateway, or IP Range, only VLAN ID. Neutron will assign these.
When the installation is complete, the Ansible log will be displayed on the final page.
The GUI is used only once: during the initial installation of your cloud.
For VSA you must follow the steps outlined in the VSA Configurationpage. After deployment, continue to Verifying Your Installation and Post-Installation Checklist.
To understand a cloud configuration more thoroughly and to learn how to make any changes later, visit these documentation pages:
HP Helion OpenStack 2.0 Input Model
Using Git for Configuration Management
